subject: Croatia Gets The Gold
event: Sorry, Portugal. When I put up the post about my Portuguese publisher winning the gold medal for being the first to release a translation of A DANCE WITH DRAGONS (see below), a number of readers in Croatia wrote me to say, no, the Croatian edition was out first. I had not seen the Croatian edition, or even a jpeg of its cover... but now I have. They were right. Croatia was first. Portugal was second. Croatia gets the gold, Portugal the silver. (The bronze remains to be determined, so far as I know). Both Croatia and Portugal split the book into two volumes, and have thusfar released only the first half. Here's the Croatian cover for volume one of DANCE: And here's their cover for the second part, which is not yet published, but is in the pipeline and should be out soon: Meanwhile, filming of the second season of the HBO series in currently underway in Dubrovnik, so Croatia is doubly blessed. A lot of Croatians have been hired as extras and crew, and a few have speaking roles as well. Portugal, on the other hand, gets a visit from me next spring. So everybody wins. I hope. Enjoy the read, whatever language you may be reading in.

props.taglist: foreign editions, a dance with dragons

comments.article: unfortunately your books are not translated into Ukrainian at all...
Ну это разве проблема? Можно и на русском почитать.
Dubrovnik is replacing what? Dragonstone? Somewhere in Dorne? One of the Free Cities?
King's Landing and Quarth definitely and I think even some scenes of Storm's End and/or Blackwater.
Right. I would only like to add that the portuguese translation was made by one translator, while the croatian has two. That helps being super-fast ;)
Yeey :) There are some of us who are mightily unhappy not to be able to take part...Keep up the good work :)
comments.subject: Croatia Gets the Gold

comments.article:
Dear George,

I obviously wasn't provided with your proper e-mail, as you've yet to reply to any message I've sent you over the past three months. But rest assured, both volumes of "Ples zmajeva" have been published, the first (with Tyrion) on 7/26, and the second (with Arya) on 9/26, here in Croatia.

Yours sincerely, and missing from LJ ever since it blocked premium accounts from Croatia back in 2004,

Your translator,
Vladimir Cvetković Sever
Portuguese cover is better.
comments.subject: Portuguese cover

comments.article: I like Andreas Rocha's artwork, but it was very obvious the Portuguese cover was an existing work. The Croatian covers aren't the most richly detailed, but I think they should win points for actually commissioning artwork that depicts recognizable characters/scenes from the book. I get really annoyed with the “insert generic fantasy image” approach too many publisher take.
comments.subject: Re: Portuguese cover

comments.upictitle: una vecchia barbogia: Christine de Pizan
comments.article:
Italian translation (of the first third of the book) will be out on October 25, as far as I know.

In the meantime, Mr. Martin, I reached almost page 300 of Dance. But I've already read all Theon's chapters, because I couldn't resist. Thank you.

Wow, and I thought that Romanian covers were bad. Seems like Nemira - publishing house - (besides some bad translations) is doing a good job after all.

P.S. The Romanian translation is supposed to appear at the end of this year. Maybe we'll get the bronze? Or, at least, un certain regard... :))
comments.subject: :D

comments.article: I love that Tyrion is sporting his fabulous new clothing on the volume one cover :P

Spain won´t get even Top 10 position :(

I hope to be wrong, of course.

Hey George, would you ever be interested in reading a chapter from an amateur writer? My father has been writing as a hobby for years but has never been able to get a publisher on board. I'd love to see a real writers opinion of his work. A shot in the dark, but hey, for his dream is worth asking.
comments.subject: Writing

comments.article: Sorry, but no, I can't do that.
comments.subject: Re: Writing

comments.article: Do you have any plans for a signing in the UK?  I've left the wall for a while to look for new recruits...you should stop by Twitter and say hello to my fellow folk of Westeros sometime :)
comments.subject: Plans for signings?

comments.article: I will be GOH at Eastercon next year, at Heathrow.  I am sure I will do plenty of signing then.
comments.subject: Re: Plans for signings?

comments.article:
Really, it's got to be things like this that really make you realize how popular these stories are.

I recently read an Ismael Reed book in a literature class. Another student brought up the glorification of medievalism that Reed is portraying which still exists not only in classic literature and modern literature, but also in American culture in general. I think that the ASoIaF sets our sensibilities of how harsh and un-glotrious the actual medieval time period was in a realistic aspect, but also how intriguing it is another. Thanks again, George. Vegas has Spain at 3:1 for the bronze in translation.
comments.subject: Pretty Cool

comments.article: One day Portugal will be first again, since circumnavigating the globe we've on a dry spell.

I really hope Bulgaria will be the third one! :)
ADWD will be released here in late November, I think. But it will be the full text, not part 1 or something... :D
I love the Croatian cover!

Thank you.

And despite what people might say, Tyrion's nose is indeed chopped off, and the Kindly Man and the Waif (curiously tall, as she might be) have their white and black sides properly oriented. Didn't draw these myself -- Esad Ribić, Marvel's draughtsman extraordinaire, had the honor -- but I did supervise the entire production.

Now if only dear George would deign reply. And here I am instructing the local cast members in the finer points of ACOK arcana and whatnot. :/
Man why does the USA always have such lame covers?  I guess it's so the books don't seem too fantasy to be off-putting, but some of the other countries' cover art is amazing.

Although, the Croatian translation is flawed right from the start. 'Ples Zmajeva' means Dance OF the Dragons, not WITH. It would appear as a minor thing, but all those who read the book know the difference between the two.
comments.subject: Translation

comments.article:
I think thats intentional: it would be like a black sheep to have it be the only book with three words in its title while other four and future two have only two words.

Algoritam often gives itself freedom and would make even more major changes if they thought it fit better (for example, Winterfell is called Oštrozimlje which would translate into Harshwinter, King's Landing is called Kraljev Grudobran whose nearest translation would be King's Defense, etc.)
comments.subject: Re: Translation

comments.article:
Croatian translation of the title is "A Dance OF Dragons" (or, if you type it in the Google Translate, "DANCING DRAGONS" lol). I guess they shouldn't have rushed that much.
On the other hand, I guess that I'm just jealous, because we in Serbia have to wait for our "Ples sa zmajevima" until 2012, which is snafu.
(On the third hand, I read the english version)
comments.subject: DANCING DRAGONS? Seriously?

comments.upictitle: Neither Here nor Then: in control
comments.article: Yes but is there an Esperanto edition?

Glad to know you're coming here (to Portugal). Not so much about loosing that gold medal, pffff.
Anyway hope you're aware that since our volumes a devided into two, you'll have twice the trouble signing in our books, get those writing muscles in shape :P
comments.subject: Portugal visit

comments.article: My cousin in Croatia just told me that her father and brother are extras in the Dubrovnik shooting. And I am jealous! I'm here in America and nowhere near Westeros or Qarth, or the Free Cities. Sigh.
Both parts of book have been published in Croatia, although i've already read English version, now i'm going to do it in Croatian too :)

Dear Mr. Martin, could you tell me what are the odds that you got this information, and book's illustration, by one e-mail with a picture of miss Clarke and a guy in purple shirt, from Dubrovnik, holding this book? :)

Your (big) fan from that picture, Mario :)
comments.subject: book's illustration

comments.article:
I am glad that A DANCE WITH DRAGONS was first translated into Croatian, but it would be more pleased if Martin came to Croatia.
P.s. We (a lot of fans in Croatia) are delighted that the second season of the series is filming in Dubrovnik.
